109242.comment:
The provincial government should not be intervening in municipal affairs. Especially after municipalities have detailed studies before implementing things like bike lanes, detailing all of the added benefits.
It is a well known fact that having more bicycles on the road improves the capacity of traveller's on our streets, while taking up less volume, and would eliminate the need for more cars to be on the road in the first place.
This proposal is fundamentally flawed in its approach as it does not recognize bikers as commuters.
Promoting these bike lanes, instead of removing or relocating them is a crucial mistake that will only make congestion worse as time passes.
I urge this government to reconsider and abandon this bill.

109243.comment:
Why are you doubling down on your bad decisions here? An amendment detailing the removal of specific lanes in Toronto when no review of them has been done by the province as was originally proposed would happen - really? A removal that contradicts all existing evidence (data, studies, pilots, community consultations, expert opinions, environmental improvement plans, etc) which all tell the opposite story of what you are assuming they do.
Bike lanes IMPROVE traffic and make roads safer for ALL users! You can't ignore the facts.
Keep Bloor/Danforth, Yonge & University bike lanes in Toronto. Keep other existing bike lanes across cities in Ontario. Allow municipalities to make decisions to build MORE bike lanes.
Also, use an environmental scan before you build things like highways! Don't sneak in lines within other legislations to circumvent useful protocols/process like an environmental scan before building something that might ruin the environment and wildlife in Ontario! Prove it is safe to build it, follow processes in place, consult Ontarians, then build it if it makes sense to do so!

109244.comment:
The update that requires removal of existing bloor, Yonge and university lanes makes this so much worse. Those are some of the safest areas of the city to ride, and encourage many people to ride, where they would have taken a car instead. Removing that safety encourages those people back into cars. Picture every cyclist you see, in a car instead, and imagine the increase in grid lock. Putting people on bikes, takes cars off the street and makes traffic lighter.
This bill has no basis in reality, is ill-defined for its own intended purpose and should be entirely scrapped.

109246.comment:
"In alignment with these objectives, Ontario is looking to fight gridlock and get drivers where they need to go faster. Prescribed municipalities would be required to seek provincial approval to allow for the implementation of new bicycle lanes (“bike lanes”) that require the removal of an existing lane of traffic."
Hello! It feels highly inappropriate that the Government of Ontario is making a conclusion that the removal of bike lanes will have any impact in "fighting gridlock and getting drivers where they need to go faster" without doing any sort of evidence-based due diligence.
Study after study shows that multimodal transportation improves road traffic (by getting people off the road); adding hundreds of thousands of additional car trips from folks no longer able to bike to work doesn't reduce the number of cars.
Even beyond the incorrect conclusion that removing travel options will speed up cars, a broader question is to be made as to why taxpayers that drive cars are being prioritized over those that don't, or can't.

109247.comment:
This doesn't seem to be going in the right direction. We should be encouraging more use of public transit and bikes instead of cars.
As a cyclist myself, I will feel much more unsafe biking on those busy roads if the bike lanes are removed. If they are removed, I will be taking up an entire lane of traffic, going the same speed as I was in a bike lane (or slower because of traffic) which will actually make traffic worse compared to if I was on a separated bike lane.
This decision seems to lack common sense and has no regard for the safety of bicyclists. This should also be a municipal issue, and not a provincial issue.

109249.comment:
This bill is an atrocious waste of taxpayer money, ripping out perfectly good cycling infrastructure and putting up red tape for no benefit. There is no evidence to support this bill and the City's own data shows that travel times have not increased, emergency response times have not been impacted, and local businesses have seen economic boosts. This is also undemocratic as Toronto just had a municipal election where bike infrastructure expansion was a wedge issue, and the city voted in favour of keeping their existing plans to expand the network and provide a safe alternative transportation network.
Stop meddling in municipal affairs and focus on getting transit projects moving, getting housing built, and getting hospitals funded. This is the biggest waste of time and resources I have seen your government undertake. This is not based in reality and you have provided no evidence to support this legislation. You have also not provided any details on what criteria you would need to add new bike infrastructure, how it could be accomplished, or what alternatives solutions would look like.
Please scrap this bill as this is a huge waste of time and money. Toronto is one of the densest areas in North America and no amount of road space will reduce the congestion of everyone needing to drive for every trip. Please let cities continue with their transportation plans which address all transportation needs, from walking, to biking, to driving, to trucking, and everything in between. You do not have the capacity or knowledge to engage with every project, collect data on every street, or be involved with every consultation.
This is a total government overreach and is undemocratic. Shameful to see this happening in the province I love which has been making such great progress on making our cities livable and welcoming to residents of all ages.
This policy will result in dead Ontarians. Reverse your decision now.

109252.comment: I live in Etobicoke close to the Bloor bike lanes.  I use them often, and would like for my children and the children of others in our area to use them to safely get around.  This legislation ignores the mandate given to Toronto's mayor and city council, who were elected in a platform of bike lanes.  It ignores the petitions of UofT on safety, the annex BIA on the lanes helping their business, and frankly any evidence based approach to fighting gridlock and increasing safety.  The lives of our children should not be a tool the government uses to buy votes from wealthy donors and people who don't live in our neighborhoods.  This bill is shameful.

109253.comment: I rely on the Bloor and University bike lanes to get to my job safety.  I rely on them to visit my parents with my 7 year old son.  I am deeply disappointed that the province of Ontario wants to waste my tax dollars to remove existing infrastructure.   These actions show that the government does not care about spending money wisely, or keeping it's citizens safe.

109256.comment:
I am enormously upset to hear about the Ford government's plan to rip out major bike lanes in Toronto and prevent many future bike lanes.
First of all, there is NO evidence provided that these bike lanes create gridlock. In fact, by making it safer to bike in Toronto, bike lanes take cars off the road and help reduce gridlock.
Secondly, bike lanes make it much safer for riders to get around the city, and encourage more people to commute this way.  This is good for the city. And it is good for cyclists and public health, because it is healthier than driving all the time.
Thirdly, getting people on bicycles is important for reducing climate change, and must be considered as part of the larger strategy.
Fourthly, why is this even the province's business?  The City of Toronto has the staff, the know-how and expertise to determine the best transportation options.  This is clearly overreach by the province.
I feel extremely strongly about this issue and am willing to get politically involved to stop it from happening.  It is a backwards move and we need to be going forward.

109257.comment: Not supporting this, as there are study shows that proper built bike lanes will not cause traffic congestion, it prompt green transportation, ease traffic congestion. Looks other city, like Vancouver BC, Norway, Finland, New York, they all have bike lanes built in the city. proper bike lanes is human centric design, promote better life for the citizens. Especially for Toronto, public transit is not reliable, and so expensive, proper bike lanes is essential.

109258.comment:
Bike lanes on Bloor St., Yonge St., and University Ave are critical fornthe safety of riders and should not be removed. Bike rider concentrations are high in denser parts of the city and are highly utilized. Opening those areas for cars will not reduce gridlock, the volume of cars is simply too high, with too many stoplights.
Further, the provicial government is overreaching by getting involved in minor Municipal matters like bike lanes. The provincial government does not have a good enough understanding or knowledge on the daily traffic functions of a city, and should not involve itself.

109259.comment:
There is significant data showing that biking has increased significantly in Toronto.
"Bike Share Toronto statistics show that ridership on its network of shared bikes has increased dramatically since 2015, when 665,000 bike trips were made annually. In 2023, that shot up to 5.7 million trips."
https://www.cbc.ca/news/science/bike-lanes-impacts-1.7358319
In terms of the environment this is significantly reducing both grid lock and reducing emissions from using vehicles. There is a direct correlation with improving bike infrastructure and increase biking.
"That’s because cycling has a carbon footprint of just 33 grams of CO2 per mile traveled. That’s up to 30 times lower than that of a fossil fuel car, and even less than that of walking or taking public transportation. "
.
If we're serious about the environment and reducing gridlock this is no data to show this helping overall. Anyone driving those streets at rush hour can see there are other points causing the congestion (ie. People trying to get onto the Gardiner). If we're serious about improving congestion and the environment we would find ways to get people out of cars and onto other modes of transportation.

109260.comment: This is a ridiculous bill that has no basis in fact or engineering principals. Countless studies show that bike lanes reduce traffic congestion over the long term. This also completely ignores the EA process that took place prior to it's construction. Its a total waste of money to rip up newly constructed infrastructure because some people are abusing their new powers. Finally, this is a municipal road and should be designed and run as seen fit by the rightfully elected municipal council. Why should someone in Thunder Bay, London or Ottawa get a say on how Toronto develops specific roads. Stop micromanaging municipalities and focus on important provincial issues like healthcare.

109261.comment: I fully support the bike lane removal.  These bike lanes make no sense as you move away from the city core and have been highly disruptive to businesses and families.  Designated bike routes along lower traffic routes make more sense than bike routes everywhere.  This was not well thought out and has lowered the standard of living in the city rather than enhanced it.
